summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a temporary restraining order against a Texas-based Border Patrol agent accused of unlawfully using excessive force in connection with an alleged terrorist attack.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in El Paso, Texas, alleges that, on June 7, 2010, Sergio Hernandez, a 15-year-old Mexican citizen without family in the United States, took a position on the Mexican side of a culvert where a group of young men began throwing rocks at him. The complaint alleges that Agent Mesa fired several shots across the border, causing the agent to be fatally injured.  According to the complaint, the defendants' claims were dismissed on the basis of "special factors" that the court deemed relevant to the issues of national security and foreign law enforcement.”  The complaint further alleges that the defendants were not entitled to a Bivens remedy when, in fact, they were entitled to one based on the facts of the case.  In a parallel action, the U.N. Office of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced that it has issued an order suspending the suspension of the suspension pending an investigation by the Office of Inspector General of the Department of Justice, which is conducting an examination of the alleged violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and that the Court should consider whether to extend the suspension for a second time.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the Mexican authorities have consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins them from violating the federal securities laws and orders them to pay disgorgement and prejudgment interest in the amount of $10,000, which will be determined by the court at a later date.  Separately, a federal district court in Arizona has also ruled against extending the suspension to a third defendant.  On September 24, 2017, the Honorable Judge William J. Wilkie of the United Kingdom entered an order permanently enjoining the suspension from future violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c) and (d) the books and records of the federal government.  Wilkie has agreed to a permanent injunction against further violations of Section 5 of the books, and to a five-year officer-and-director bar from serving as an officer or director of a public agency. The order also prohibits Wilkie from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security-related product or service, including the right to a penny stock.
